abstract.p: Fred Alger Management executives Frederick Alger 3rd, Daniel Chung and Zachary Karabell, in open letter to Pres Bush, urge that $1,000 tax be imposed on personal vehicles that get less than 30 miles per gallon (S)

block.p: The guys who run Fred Alger Management have some advice for President Bush, but not on the subject of Social Security, health savings accounts or anything else that might help their business. They want him to tax gas guzzlers into oblivion.

In an open letter to the president, Frederick M. Alger III, the firm's chairman; Daniel C. Chung, its president; and Zachary Karabell, a senior vice president, said that importing millions of barrels of oil a day, mostly to burn in cars and trucks, leads to ''a substantial trade deficit and an unhealthy reliance on energy from the Middle East.''

In an open letter to the president, Frederick M. Alger III, the firm's chairman; Daniel C. Chung, its president; and Zachary Karabell, a senior vice president, said that importing millions of barrels of oil a day, mostly to burn in cars and trucks, leads to ''a substantial trade deficit and an unhealthy reliance on energy from the Middle East.''
Their solution is to slap a $1,000 tax on personal vehicles that get less than 30 miles per gallon. They reckon that could generate $200 billion, a useful sum in a time of record federal deficits.
